page.title: 14 Silverton Hallhouses
page.content:
We believe Silverton is unique amongst Devon villages in having a row of fourteenth century {Hallhouses. These are of cruck beam construction with walls made of Devon cob and roofs of thatch. They derive their name from the fact that they were originally built of a single storey without a chimney. Smoke from the fires found its way out through the roof, and evidence of this can still be seen on the roof beams today. At a later date, this large room was divided by means of an upper floor, and a chimney was added to the outside wall.
Fortunately, despite their thatched roofs which increased the risk of fire, the{Hallhouses}have survived to the present day and are now listed buildings.
